title: Knee Pain Case Study: A 45-Year-Old Male with Gradual Onset of Knee Pain
clinical_history: A 45-year-old male, John, presents with a 3-month history of gradual onset of knee pain. He reports that the pain started after increasing his running distance and intensity for a charity event. Initially, the pain was mild and only occurred after running, but over time, it has progressed to occur during and after running, as well as with daily activities such as climbing stairs and getting up from a seated position.

nprs.affected_area: Anterior knee pain, described as a dull ache
Medial knee pain, described as a sharp stabbing pain

aggrevating_factors: Running, climbing stairs, getting up from a seated position, and prolonged standing
picture: A 24-hour picture of the patient's knee pain shows that the pain is worse in the morning and evening, with a gradual increase in pain throughout the day.
easing_factors: Rest, ice, and over-the-counter pain medication
past_history: The patient has a history of a left ankle fracture 10 years ago, which was treated with open reduction and internal fixation. He has also experienced intermittent lower back pain over the past 5 years.
medical_history: The patient is generally healthy, but has high cholesterol and is slightly overweight.
personal_history: The patient is married with two children and works as an accountant. He is an avid runner and enjoys outdoor activities.
imaging: X-rays of the knee show mild joint space narrowing and osteophytes, consistent with early-stage osteoarthritis.
